Award.AwardTitle: CPS:GOALI:Synergy: Maneuver and Data Optimization for High Confidence Testing of Future Automotive Cyberphysical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses urgent challenges in high confidence validation and verification of automotive vehicles due to on-going and anticipated introduction of advanced, connected and autonomous vehicles into mass production. Since such vehicles operate across both physical and cyber domains, faults can occur in traditional physical components, in cyber components (i.e., algorithms, processors, networks, etc.), or in both. Thus, advanced vehicles need to be tested for both physical and cyber-related fault conditions. The goal of this project is to develop theory, methods, and novel tools for generating and optimizing test trajectories and data inputs that can uncover both physical and cyber faults of future automotive vehicles. The level of vehicle reliability and safety achieved for current vehicles is remarkable considering their mass production, low cost, and wide range of operating conditions. If successful, the research advances made in this project will enable achieving similar levels of reliability and safety for future vehicles relying on advanced driver assistance technologies, connectivity and autonomy. The project will advance the ﬁeld of cyber-physical systems, in general, and their lifecycle management, in particular. The validation and veriﬁcation theory and methodology for cyberphysical systems will be expanded for uncovering anomalies and faults, especially using comprehensive case-based and optimization-based techniques for test scenario generation.

The theoretical advances and case studies will contribute to the state-of-the-art in optimal control theory, game theory, information theory, data collection and processing, autonomous and connected vehicles, and automotive control. Sampling-based vehicle data acquisition and vehicle-aware data management strategies will be developed which can be applied more broadly, e.g., to cloud-based vehicle prognostics / conditional maintenance and mobile health-monitoring devices. Finally, approaches for efficient on-board data collection and aggregation will be implemented in a Cyber-physical system (CPS) Black Box prototype. The development of a vehicle-aware data management system (VDMS) will be pursued, leading to optimized use of data mining and compression inside the CPS Black Box to aggressively reduce the communication and computational costs. Synergistically with theoretical and methodological advances, automotive case studies will be undertaken with both realistic simulations and real experiments in collaboration with an industrial partner (AVL).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project addressed urgent challenges in high confidence validation and verification of automotive vehicles due to on-going and anticipated introduction of advanced, connected and autonomous vehicles intro mass production.  Specific outcomes were as follows:

Intellectual merits:

1. In this project, a framework based on behavioral game theory for modeling the interactions between drivers/vehicles in traffic scenarios that involve multiple human-driven and/or autonomous vehicles has been established. For highway or urban traffic scenarios, this framework generates a set of interactive driver models with different driving styles and driving intentions. These models are shown, in comparison against traffic data, to be able to represent the interactive behavior of real human drivers in traffic.

2. A traffic simulator, called GTTS, has been developed based on the interactive driver models as a platform for virtual testing, verification, and validation of autonomous vehicle control systems. This simulator can facilitate discovering faults in given control algorithms, e.g., conditions under which the algorithm may cause unsafe driving behavior, record these faults for post-analysis, and statistically evaluate the safety and robustness of the control algorithm based on Monte Carlo testing. Verification results for three autonomous vehicle control algorithms in the literature were reported as case studies.

3. A model-free trajectory optimization-based falsification approach to performing guided search for faults in a given control system has been developed. The approach has also been extended from its basic version to enhanced versions that can handle time-delay systems and  hybrid systems with mode switches. This falsification approach was demonstrated on three automotive-related case studies, including applications to an adaptive cruise control system, to a gasoline engine air-to-fuel ratio control system, and to vehicle rollover test generation.

4.  The Smart Black Box (SBB) has been proposed for efficient recording of event data over long-term driving of connected and autonomous vehicles. The SBB architecture has been defined, a method to select data compression factors based on event data values to fit data into limited SBB on-board storage has been proposed, and deep learning-based object detection and segmentation algorithms for quality evaluation of SBB collected data have been established. The event data collected by the SBB can inform trajectories and data inputs for testing of future vehicles.

5. Two components for the SBB, called VerdictDB and VerdictML, have been developed to analyze in real time and quickly train various machine learning models (e.g., for regression, classification, and factor analysis) on massive volumes of data.

6. An unsupervised algorithm has been developed for anomaly detection in driving videos. The algorithm detects anomalous traffic events based on prediction of normal trajectory and comparison between the predicted trajectory and the actual trajectory. This algorithm can be used in the SBB for determining event data values.  A new spatial-temporal ACU metric was proposed as a supplement to existing evaluation metrics for video action detection.

Broader impacts:


7. The results were disseminated through journal and conference articles, book chapters and presentations.

8. The GTTS traffic simulator has been published in the Verification Tool Library of the NSF Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization (https://cps-vo.org/group/verification_tools/tool/GTTS) and has been used by other researchers as a testing and verification tool to support their research into autonomous vehicle control algorithms.

9. The project provided training opportunities for graduate students (Ph.D. and Master students) and undergraduate students at the University of Michigan.

10. The A3D dataset (https://github.com/MoonBlvd/tad-IROS2019) has been created which contains 1500 videos of anomalous traffic events with temporal annotations. Another larger-scale DoTA dataset  (https://github.com/MoonBlvd/Detection-of-Traffic-Anomaly) has been also developed, which provides anomalous object and anomalous category annotations in addition to temporal annotations.  These datasets can be used by other researchers in the areas of video anomaly detection, action recognition, and online action detection.

11. The University of Michigan team has been collaborating in this project with AVL, a worldwide supplier of testing equipment for the automotive industry. The industry outreach also involved several other automotive companies. A selection of project outcomes has been presented during outreach activities to elementary school students to motivate their interests in science and technology.
